journal-meta.journal-title: The Journal of Defense Modeling and Simulation: Applications, Methodology, Technology

title-group.article-title: Modeling of dynamics, guidance, and control systems of air-to-surface missiles

article-meta.aff: 1The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Defense Industries Research and Development Institute (TÜBİTAK-SAGE), Turkey
2Mechanical Engineering Department, Middle East Technical University, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Bülent Özkan, The Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Defense Industries Research and Development Institute (TÜBİTAK-SAGE), P. K. 16, 06261, Mamak, Ankara, Turkey. Email: bozkan@sage.tubitak.gov.tr

fn.p: Bülent Özkan has BSc, MSc and PhD degrees, all in mechanical engineering. Currently, he works as a chief researcher at the Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Defense Industries Research and Development Institute (TÜBİTAK-SAGE), Ankara, Turkey.
M Kemal Özgören is a full professor at the Middle East Technical University, Mechanical Engineering Department, Ankara, Turkey.

Gökmen Mahmutyazicioğlu has BSc, MSc, and PhD degrees, all in mechanical engineering. Currently, he works as a chief researcher at the Scientific and Technological Research Council of Turkey, Defense Industries Research and Development Institute (TÜBİTAK-SAGE), Ankara, Turkey.

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Resuability, Interoperability and Composability in Air Warfare Simulations

abstract.p: In this study, the generic dynamic models of air-to-surface missiles are given in addition to the related guidance and control schemes. In this extent, two-part missile configurations are considered as well as the traditional single-part missile geometries. The dynamic modelling part consists of the general equations of motion for both of the mentioned types of missile configurations, aerodynamic modelling and corresponding transfer functions, which are used in the design of missile autopilots. Further, the notable guidance laws applicable to such missiles are given along with the relevant autopilot, or missile control system, models. Regarding the mission profile of these munitions, the target is modelled as a surface vehicle moving on the ground. After conducting some computer simulations based on the proposed models, the study is concluded by a general evaluation section.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: The guidance and control of air-to-surface missiles have been among popular problems in control engineering in recent years. When considering moving and manoeuvring targets, the problems get more complicated. In this sense, one of the primary factors indicating the success of air-to-surface missiles, which are used against stationary, moving and even manoeuvring targets, is the guidance law and relevant control system considered. Apart from the final miss distance values, the simplicity and ease of implementation issues are also important in deciding on a guidance law.1–3

When the moving or manoeuvring targets are considered, the effectiveness of the missile gains more importance. In this sense, the two-part missiles come into the picture as a viable alternative to their single-part counterparts. In particular, the better stability and higher steady-state accuracy properties of the two-part missiles have put them ahead of the single-part missiles. This mainly results from the fact that the diverting effect of the misalignment moment originated by the thrust of the rocket motor is minimized by separating the rear part of the missile via a roller bearing in two-part missiles. The mentioned configuration change leads the flow around the two-part missile to become more laminar than the flow over its single-part counterpart in turn. However, their higher costs make them disadvantageous over the single-part ones.4

In the physical sense, guidance laws are derived with regard to the missile–target engagement geometry which is considered to orient the missile towards an intended target. Looking at the relevant literature, it is seen that the guidance laws are compared with respect to their implementation issues, acceleration requirements and final miss distance properties. Moreover, they are evaluated according to their compatibility depending on the target and engagement characteristics regarded. The mentioned studies are conducted by taking into account the possible flight scenario, and the performance characteristics of missiles are also investigated under challenging engagement conditions.1,4–6 In this sense, the guidance laws developed for guided missiles can be categorized with respect to certain aspects. One of the categorization classes covers the type of resulting guidance commands. Namely, the guidance laws generating commands to the missile control system in the form of linear acceleration components can be called ‘acceleration-based guidance laws’, whereas those dictating command signals in the form of orientation angles can be called ‘angle-based guidance laws’. Since the guidance command constitutes its reference signal, the missile control system, usually known as ‘missile autopilot’, is usually designed according to the type of the command signal.7

In this study, the dynamic models of single- and two-part air-to-surface missiles are presented as well as the relevant control system schemes obeying the commands generated by the regarded guidance laws. Taking a moving surface target model into account, the performance characteristics of the mentioned types of missiles are examined.

sec.title: 2.1 Equations of motion of the missiles
sec.p:
In this study, both single- and two-part air-to-surface missile configurations are considered. Once the governing differential equations of motion for a more complicated two-part missile have been derived, they can be easily adapted to single-part ones. Here, an aerodynamically controlled canard-type two-part missile configuration is considered as schematically represented in Figure 1. The mentioned missile model is a combination of two relatively rotating parts that are connected to each other by means of a roller bearing. Here,
u →

C1, C2 and CM denote the mass centres of the front body, or body 1, rear body, or body 2, and entire missile body, respectively, with definitions that xM and d12 indicate the distances from C1 to CM and from C1 to C2. As shown, δj (j = 1, 2, 3 and 4) represents the fin deflections of the aerodynamic control surfaces, that is, the canards.

For the single-part missiles, the necessary equations of motion can be adapted from the expressions obtained for the preceding two-part configuration by treating body 1 and body 2 as rigidly connected to each other and hence eliminating the uncontrolled roll dynamics of body 2 formulated in Equation (9). Thus, considering the same definitions stated above with the new definition that Ia represents the axial moment of inertia component of the missile, the next expressions can be written for the dynamics of the single-part missiles:4,8,9

In most of the planned flight trajectory, the air-to-surface missiles have a non-thrusted motion. Thus, the force and moment terms related to the thrust will vanish for this stage, that is, XT = YT = ZT = LT = MT = NT = 0. Furthermore, the uncontrolled roll dynamics of the two-part missiles will be out of concern regarding their controlled motion. Hence, the equations for both single- and two-part air-to-surface missiles can be simplified to the following form:

sec.title: 2.2 Aerodynamic model of the missiles
sec.p: In this study, a linearized aerodynamic model is considered by expressing the aerodynamic force and moment components within Equations (5)–(17) in terms of the dynamic pressure (q∞), missile cross-sectional area (SM) and missile diameter (dM), as given below:4,10
As ρ represents the air density at the related altitude and π ≈ 3.14, q∞ and SM can be calculated using the following equalities:11

Indicating the magnitude of the missile velocity vector by vM, Cx, Cy, Cz, Cl, Cm and Cn, coefficients can be written as linear functions of the angle of attack (α), side-slip angle (β), aileron, elevator and rudder deflections (δa, δe and δr, respectively), p, q and r, as given below:4
Here, τ = dM / (2vM) and Cx0 is a static aerodynamic force component in the axial direction.

sec.title: 2.3 Transfer functions of the missiles
sec.p: In order to design the roll, pitch and yaw autopilots, the transfer functions between the selected inputs and outputs are required. These transfer functions are obtained regarding the linearized model of the missile. Thus, they can be generated from Equations (18)–(23) by taking the gravity as an external disturbance, that is, gx = gy = gz = 0, as follows:4

where ϕ1 denotes the roll angle of the entire missile while it corresponds to the roll angle of body 1 for two-part missile configurations and az and ay represent the lateral acceleration components of the entire missile in pitch and yaw directions, respectively. The gains Lδ, Lp1, nz0, nz1, nz2, dp0, dp1, ny0, ny1, ny2, dy0 and dy1 are functions of the dimensional, kinematic and aerodynamic parameters of the missile.4

sec.title: 3. Guidance laws
sec.p: As mentioned above, the guidance laws considered can be evaluated into two main groups: acceleration- and angle-based guidance laws. In application, these laws are, in general, utilized during the terminal guidance phase of the missile–target engagement scenarios.

sec.title: 3.1 Acceleration-based guidance laws
sec.p: In this content, proportional navigation guidance (PNG), velocity pursuit guidance (VPG) and augmented proportional navigation guidance (APNG) laws can be evaluated.

sec.title: 3.1.1 Proportional navigation guidance law
sec.p: As the most widely used guidance law for missiles, the PNG law can be expressed regarding the yaw and pitch planes of the missile–target engagement geometry in the following fashion:4,10

where
a

and

indicate the command acceleration components in the yaw and pitch planes, respectively. Moreover, N2 and N3 show the effective navigation ratios, while λy and λp indicate, respectively, the yaw and pitch angles of the line-of-sight (LOS) between the missile and target. Here, the flight path angle components of the missile in yaw and pitch planes (ηm and γm) can be calculated using the following expressions:12,13

where c(σ) = cos(σ), s(σ) = sin(σ) for any angle σ and ϕ, θ and Ψ denote the roll, pitch and yaw angles of the missile, respectively. The coefficients c1, c2, s1 and s2 are functions of missile kinematic parameters.

sec.title: 3.1.2 Velocity pursuit guidance law
sec.p:
Taking N2 and N3 coefficients as unity in Equations (46) and (47), the PNG law turns into the VPG law. In this approach, the aim is to align the missile velocity vector (
v →
M /
O E
) and LOS vector (
r →
T / M
) and thus to keep the direction of
v →
M /
O E
as indicating the target.7

sec.title: 3.1.3 Augmented proportional navigation guidance law
sec.p: When moving or manoeuvring targets are under consideration, the APNG law comes into the picture as a viable choice. In this scheme, the guidance commands to the lateral acceleration components of the missile are determined by adding the product of the half of the relevant lateral acceleration component of the target by the corresponding effective navigation ratio to the command expressions derived for the PNG law as given in Equations (46) and (47). Thus, the APNG commands are determined in the following manner as aT2 and aT3 terms from the target acceleration vector:1,6
where aT2 and aT3 stand for the components of the target acceleration vectors on the yaw and pitch planes of the missile, respectively.

sec.title: 3.2 Angle-based guidance laws
sec.p: As the most commonly used angle-based guidance laws, the body pursuit guidance (BPG) and linear homing guidance (LHG) laws can be considered within the scope of this study.

sec.title: 3.2.1 Body pursuit guidance law
sec.p:
In the BPG approach, it is intended to put the longitudinal axis of the missile, that is, the
u →
1
( b )
axis, onto the LOS between the missile and target. Thus, the guidance commands in the pitch and yaw planes (θc and Ψc) can be derived in the following manner as θ and Ψ, indicating the pitch and yaw angles of the missile, respectively:1,4

sec.title: 3.2.2 Linear homing guidance law
sec.p: In the LHG approach, it is intended to keep the missile always on the collision triangle that is formed by the missile, target and predicted intercept point. For this purpose, the most appropriate way is to orient the missile velocity vector towards the predicted intercept point at which the missile–target collision will occur after a while. Then, the resulting guidance commands will be in the form of the flight path angles of the missile in the yaw and pitch planes as given below:4,14

where Δx, Δy and Δz show the position components of the target relative to the missile, while vTx, vTy and vTz are the components of the target velocity vector in F0. In these formulas, Δt represents the time-to-target parameter.
Although its governing Equations in (54) and (55) have non-linear characteristics, the LHG law imposes a linear trajectory from the missile to the target, as its name implies.

sec.title: 4. Missile control system
sec.p: In order to realize the command signals generated by the guidance laws, whether acceleration or angle based, two kinds of missile control systems, that is, missile autopilots, can be designed for controlling the motion of the missile in its lateral directions. That is, assuming that the roll angle of the missile is nullified prior to the motion in its lateral directions, the control systems can be constructed for the pitch- and yaw-plane motions of the missile. The first type of control system mentioned above is built to execute the acceleration-type command signals, whereas the other is based on the angle-based guidance commands. Both of the control systems consist of a controller, a control actuation system (CAS), gyroscopes, accelerometers and plant, that is, missile.

sec.title: 4.1 Acceleration control system
sec.p: An acceleration control system is designed in order to obey the guidance commands, that is, reference acceleration commands, generated by the PNG, VPG, and APNG laws such that they operate independently in the pitch and yaw planes. In this sense, the control system designed for the pitch-plane motion of the missile can be easily adapted to the yaw control system if the considered missile configuration has a rotational symmetry as seen in most cases.

Assuming that the roll motion of the missile is compensated by a faster roll autopilot, the control system for the pitch-plane motion of the missile can be designed by considering the classical PI (proportional plus integral) control action with the contribution of the pitch damping as represented by the following transfer function from the desired acceleration (azd) to the actual acceleration (az):4

where Tp, np1, np2, ap1, ap2 and ap3 are the terms functions of the dimensional, kinematic and aerodynamic parameters of the missile. Here, Tp stands for the integral time constant of the considered control action.4
For the mentioned control system, the characteristic polynomial of the transfer function in Equation (56) is

In order to determine the controller gains, the third-order Butterworth polynomial presented below can be used by placing the three poles of the control system to desired locations in accordance with the desired bandwidth value (ωc):4,15,16
This way, the controller gains can be found by matching Equations (57) and (58).

In a similar manner, the transfer function from the desired acceleration (ayd) to the actual acceleration (ay) for the yaw-plane control system can also be established as follows. Here, Ty, ny1, ny2, ay1, ay2 and ay3 are the parameters related to the dimensional, kinematic and aerodynamic parameters of the missile for the yaw-plane motion, respectively. Moreover, Ty denotes the integral time constant of the used control action:4

sec.title: 4.2 Angle control system
sec.p:
In order for the missile to realize the guidance commands produced by the BPG and LHG laws, a state feedback-type angle control system in which the integral of the error between the reference and actual values of the controlled state variable, that is, flight path angle, is defined as an additional state variable and is constructed for the motion of the missile both in its pitch and yaw planes. In this scheme, the guidance commands generated by the BPG law in terms of the orientation angles of the missile with respect to the ground, that is, θc and Ψc, are converted into the flight path angle commands, (
η m c
and
γ m c
), as below:4
On the other hand, the commands to the flight path angle components resulted from the LHG law can be directly utilized.4

Considering the roll-free motion of the missile in the pitch plane and taking the gravity effect as an external disturbance, the closed-loop transfer function of the angle control system between the desired and actual values of the flight path angle (γmd and γm) in the yaw plane can be found from the resulting expressions in the following manner:4
where nγ1, nγ2, nγ3, dγ1, dγ2, dγ3 and dγ4 are the terms for the functions of the dimensional, kinematic and aerodynamic parameters of the missile, respectively.4
The characteristic polynomial of the transfer function in Equation (62) is as follows:
In order to determine the controller gains, Equation (63) should be equated to the fourth-order Butterworth polynomial as given below:4

Similarly, the angle control system can be adapted for the yaw-plane motion of the missile with the transfer function from the desired flight path angle (ηmd) to its actual value (ηm) in the following fashion. Here, nη1, nη2, nη3, dη1, dη2, dη3 and dη4 are the terms for the functions of the dimensional, kinematic and aerodynamic parameters of the missile, respectively.4

sec.title: 5. Target kinematics
sec.p:
Regarding the target as a ground vehicle moving on the Earth surface, the kinematic parameters describing its motion on the horizontal plane are the normal and tangential acceleration components (
a T n
and
a T t
), magnitude of the target velocity vector (vT), and heading angle (ηt). Specifying
a T n
and
a T t
, as well as the initial values of the target velocity and the heading angle (vT0 and ηt0) as t0 indicates the initiation of the missile–target engagement, vT and ηt can be obtained as functions of time by the following integrals, with σ being the integration variable:
Afterwards, with the initial values of xT0 and yT0, the position of the target on the horizontal plane can be described by the following equations as functions of time:

Actually, the motion surface of the target is not planar. Yet, since the variations in the vertical direction are very small compared to the displacements in the horizontal plane, the altitude of the target is taken to be constant in the modelling as given below:

sec.title: 6. Missile–target engagement model
sec.p: In the missile–target engagement geometry, the LOS distance (rT/M), λy and λp can be obtained from the following equations:

Since a ground target is considered in the study, the total miss distance (dmiss) at the end of the missile–target engagement, that is, at t = tF, can be calculated from the following formula, just as the vertical component of rTM becomes zero, that is, ∅z = 0:

sec.title: 7. Computer simulations
sec.p: As an example to the implementation of the models given above, the performance characteristics of a single-part air-to-surface missile can be obtained by conducting relevant computer simulations with consistent numerical values of the necessary system parameters as shown in Table 1.

tr.td: Cant angle of the fixed tail fins

sec.p: Combining the models given above along with a strapdown, or body-fixed, seeker with a field of view of ±30° both in the pitch and yaw directions, the entire guidance and control scheme is constructed and the missile–target engagement is simulated for different situations with this model.17 The PNG, VPG, APNG, BPG and LHG laws are implemented for the zero initial heading error value of the missile against both stationary and manoeuvring targets with a constant speed of 90 km/h and a manoeuvre level of 0.3g on its motion plane (g = 9.81 m/s2). The change in the target speed, that is, its tangential acceleration component, is disregarded. The effective navigation ratios of the PNG (N2 and N3) are taken to be 3 in both the yaw and pitch planes.1 The final bandwidth values of both the acceleration and angle control systems are set to 5 Hz (ωc = 31.4 rad/s). The CAS is modelled as a second-order system with a bandwidth value of 20 Hz such that its dynamics does not affect the control system dynamics and it is assumed that the angular deflections of the control fins connected to the CAS vary within the range of ±20°. The operating frequencies of the gyroscopes and accelerometers are assigned to be 110 Hz. The numerical values of the essential missile parameters used in the relevant computer simulations conducted for the terminal guidance phase of the missile–target engagement process are given in Table 1.

Aerodynamic coefficients are computed for the M∞ range of 0.3–2.7, δe and δr ranges of between −10° and 10° and α and β ranges of between −17° and 19°. Depending on the current state of the missile, the appropriate values of the aerodynamic terms are continuously calculated using relevant look-up tables prepared for the ranges given below. For the values of the concerned parameters other than the numbers given here, the corresponding coefficients are computed by making interpolation or extrapolation. The obtained values are used for the yaw motion as well, with regard to the rotational symmetry of the missile.4 The initial values of the missile and target kinematic parameters related to the engagement are shown in Table 2.

caption.p: Initial conditions of the missile and target kinematic parameters

sec.p: Thus, the computer simulations are performed in the MATLAB® SIMULINK® environment using the entire guidance and control simulation model given in Figure 3 for the situations given above; the attained results are presented in Table 3. These results are found for the terminal miss distance, total engagement time and maximum acceleration requirement of the missile. The trajectories of the missile and target within the engagement scenarios with the PNG, VPG, APNG, BPG and LHG laws against the manoeuvring target are shown in Figures 4–8.

caption.p: MATLAB® SIMULINK® model of the missile guidance and control system.
Simulation results obtained for the control systems with constant bandwidth

fn.p: PNG: proportional navigation guidance, VPG: velocity pursuit guidance, APNG: augmented proportional navigation guidance, BPG: body pursuit guidance, LHG: linear homing guidance.

caption.p: Engagement with the proportional navigation guidance law.
Engagement with the velocity pursuit guidance law.
Engagement with the augmented proportional navigation guidance law.
Engagement with the body pursuit guidance law.
Engagement with the linear homing guidance law.

sec.title: 8. Discussion and conclusion
sec.p: In this study, the dynamic modelling of air-to-surface missiles is given along with an aerodynamic model, transfer functions and possible guidance and control schemes. In this extent, two-part missile configurations are considered along with the traditional single-part missile geometries. As mentioned above, a linearized aerodynamic model is regarded in this work. Considering planned motion profiles of the missile configurations in accordance with the intended targets, it is evaluated that this linearization does not cause significant errors in monitoring the effects of the aerodynamic force and moments on the missiles. At the end of the study, the results of a set computer simulations performed regarding a classical single-part missile configuration are presented. Looking at the results submitted in Table 3 and Figures 4–8, it is observed that the LHG law yields the smallest values in the sense of the terminal miss distance among the others, whereas it appears the worst approach when the maximum acceleration requirement criterion is considered. Actually, this undesired case is caused by the initial acceleration demand of the LHG law so as to orient the velocity vector of the missile towards the present location of the target. In fact, these high accelerations at the beginning of the missile–target engagement can be considerably lowered by implementing a varying-bandwidth missile control system.4 Moreover, when the total engagement time parameter is taken into consideration, it can be stated that all the guidance laws handled produce almost the same results. Unfortunately, these results could not be proven by actual flight data because there was no opportunity to conduct missile–target engagements in the physical world.

Based on the models presented above, the guidance and control simulations of certain types of single- and two-part guided missiles can be carried out. In this way, it becomes possible to observe their advantages and disadvantages with regard to the comparison criteria, such as terminal miss distance, total engagement time and maximum acceleration requirement. In this sense, it is observed that the two-part missile model considered becomes more stable than its single-part rival with the same dimensions and similar mass. This result is deduced from the locations of the poles of the closed-loop missile control systems, that is, missile autopilots, wherein the poles of the control system of the two-part missile lie further from the origin on the left-hand side of the complex plane. Actually, the superiority comes from the stabilization of the thrust misalignment moment by means of the missile configuration, including a low-friction roller bearing between its front and rear parts. Conversely, the single-part missile model behaves with a more manoeuvrable attitude than the two-part one. One of the reasons for this result is the relatively lower acceleration requirement of the single-part missile. The small disturbance moment caused by the uncontrolled roll motion of the rear body of the two-part missile can be evaluated as the other reason for the weaker performance of the two-part missile. In addition, the obtained results can be compared with actual flight data if some of the handled engagements can be performed in the real world.

Consequently, it can be stated that these models can be used in simulation studies of air-to-ground missiles with their own parameter values. Although the present work does not contribute to the field of defence modelling and simulation as a new simulation technology, it provides a useful tool to simulate the performances of single- and two-part missiles. In addition, different guidance laws and autopilot models can also be integrated into the proposed entire guidance and control scheme with manoeuvring target models.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
